title.narrative: Namibia Protected Landscape Conservation Areas Initiativ

description.narrative: NAMIBIA Protected Landscape Conservation Areas Initiative (NAM-PLACE).

title.narrative: Namibia Protected Landscapes Proposal to GEF
Terminal Evaluation: Namibia Protected Landscape Conservation Areas (NAMPLACE) Project

description.narrative: Landscape Conservation Areas established ensuring that land uses in areas adjacent to existing Protected Areas are compatible with biodiversity conservation objectives.
desert
desert
Environment - policy, planning and administration
Establish new Landscape Conservation Areas (LCAs)
National level best practice guidelines in place for the establishment of LCAs

comment.narrative: Draft MET Protected Area management planning policy guideline in place

National level best practice guidelines for the establishment of new landscapes in place by April 2015 (The target on â€œNational level best practices guidelines for the establishment of new LCAs in place by year 5â€? was changed to â€œNational level best practices guidelines for the establishment of new LCAs in place by April 2015â€?. MTR recommendation - This indicator is suitable; we recommend changing the target date to April 2015 as the LCAs have been established and the guidelines can now be written and approved) PSC - The timeframe was endorsed as recommended

The Project is developing lessons learned, challenges and best practices in the establishment of landscape conservation areas in Namibia. To ensure objectiveness of the process, the project contracted a consultant to develop these practices. Furthermore, the project is arranging to host a National Workshop to Share the experience. In addition to the development of these lessons learned, challenges and best practices, the project has show cased the project at various global stages that include the IUCN World Parks Congress in Sydney, Australia and the World Bank Annual Conference on Land and Policy in Washington DC, USA.

description.narrative: Constitutions in place for 5 landscapes. (The indicator and target on â€œPartnership agreements in place for 5 landscapes; Constitutions in place for 5 landscapesâ€? was changed to â€œConstitutions in place for 5 landscapesâ€? and â€œ5 LCAs with constitutions in place for 5 landscapesâ€? respectively); MTR recommendations - This indicator has been achieved but the terminology should be changed, as appropriate, to remain consistent, with clear definitions (e.g., â€œpartnership agreementsâ€? vs. â€œconstitutionsâ€?)

comment.narrative: Constitutions in place for conservancies and drafts for GWC, GSNC and GFRCC.
5 landscapes with approved constitutions in place by year 5

Partially acheived. The projet has revised Landscape Conservation Area constitutions following the decision by the Ministry of Environment and Tourism management not to sign the constitutions pending the finalization of the Protected Areas and Wildlife Management Bill. Based on the Implementation Guidelines for the National Policy on Protected Areas’ Neighbours and Resident Communities, constitutions will be signed by landscape stakeholders or the Landscape Conservation Area Association excluding the Ministry of Environment and Tourism. Once the consititutions are signed, the association will enter into a Memorandum of Unerstanding with the Ministry of Environment and Tourism for the management of the respective protected areas and adjacent land as a single landscape conservation area

description.narrative:
Landscape threats and sustainable land uses defined (setting the scene to develop regulations, standards and codes of practice); Regulations, standards and codes of practice developed for each landscape; National level best practice codes of practice in place. (The indicator and target on â€œLandscape threats and sustainable land uses defined (setting the scene to develop regulations, standards and codes of practice); Standards and codes of practice developed for each LCA; National level best practice codes of practice in placeâ€? was split into the following indictors and targets: â€œIndicator - Standards and codes of practice developed for each Landscape Conservation Areaâ€? and Target - â€œStandards and codes of practice developed for each LCA by Dec 2014â€?; and Indicator - â€œNational level best practice codes of practice in placeâ€? and Target â€œNational level best practice codes of practice in place by Dec 2015â€?) MTR recommendations - There are four components each with a different output to this indicator:
i) identification of the threats at a landscape level (already done at PPG stage)
ii) defining sustainable land uses in each LCA (already done to some extent at PPG stage but this should be included in the LCA management plans)
iii) developing standards and codes for each LCA (these have been done to some extent already but guidelines and regulations for each LCA building on the constitutions and management plans still need to be done) and
iv) Publishing the best practice codes at a national level. Thus, the first two are not relevant (as they were done in the PPG stage).
We recommend that the standards and codes (akin to guidelines and regulations) are developed for each LCA with a target date of Dec 2014; those in the GW LCA will be developed later (once the issues in this area are sorted out).
Standards and codes at a national level should then be finalised by Dec 2015.

comment.narrative: Biodiversity threats defined for all landscapes - Land use zoning maps suggesting suitable land uses at conservancy, park and complex level - Draft PWMB in place and draft constitutions for GFRCC, GSNC and GWC - Park specific regulations in place (which parks?) - Guiding principles in park M+D plans and conservancy management plans

Landscape threats and sustainable land uses defined by year 5; landscape level regulations, standards and codes of practice for biodiversity conservation in place by year 5; National level codes of practice, based on best practice, in place by year 5.
Partially acheived. The development of code of practice to be done upon completion of the development of the National Level Best Practices.

description.narrative: Infrastructure, based on approved recommended priorities, are in place for 5 landscapes.

comment.narrative: Mudumu - fire management equipment, water points; GWC - guard posts, boundary fences, fire management equipment, water points; WGB - park and farm fences, water points, guard post at DVJ; GSNC - fences, water points, guard post; GFRCC - fences, water points, guard posts, solid waste management and Radio communication at (/Ai-/Ais). (Updated in 2013 at Project Steering Committee based on needs assessment)

All infrastructure is in place for all landscapes based on assessment by December 2015 (The target on â€œInfrastructure is in place for all LCAs based on assessment by year 5â€? was changed to â€œInfrastructure is in place for all LCAs based on assessment by December 2015â€? MTR recommendations - This indicator is suitable; no suggested changes but to reiterate that the infrastructure should be relevant to the goal and objectives of the project. All infrastructure should be in place by Dec 2015

Partially achieved: In addition to the already developed infrastructure in various landscapes, the project developed further infrastructure such as the a) infrastructure supporting the Khomas Hochland Hiking Trail in Windhoek Green Belt Landscape Conservation Areas; and b) tourist game viewing hide at Santika Waterpoint in Mudumu Landscape Conservation Area. Other infrastructure development yet to be completed include the upgrading of the Sesriem Gate in Greater Sossusvlei-Namib Landscape to reduce dawn bottlenecks and office accommodation for the 4 Greater Waterberg Landscape Conservation Area conservancies.

description.narrative:
Landscape Conservation Areas (LCAs) are established and ensure that land uses in areas adjacent to existing Protected Areas are compatible with biodiversity conservation objectives, and corridors are established to sustain the viability of wildlife populations (GEF 4.5 mill USD)
(This resolution was reached at inception meeting for landscape not to pursue protected areas status due to realities on the ground influenced by the land reform program in the country)

Changes in the movement patterns of animals in relation to corridors created (The indicator and target on â€œTrends in increased abundance and distribution of selected speciesâ€? was changed to â€œChanges in the movement patterns of animals in relation to corridors createdâ€?. MTR recommendation - What may be more important than the abundance estimates (which are unlikely to change significantly over the course of this project), are i) the changes in the movement patterns of animals particularly in those areas in which the fences have been removed (as may be measured through distance travelled by and/or home range sizes of collared animals using the data that is already being collected), and ii) changes (if any) in the use of corridors by animals (usually using data from collared animals). Although the change was endorsed, the Project Steering Committee felt that due to the high costs associated with wildlife movement research using collars, the project is to use existing data.

comment.narrative: Key species collared to monitor wildlife movement in Mudumu and Greater Sossusvlei-Namib Landscapes) (Baseline changed from â€œAbundance estimates for game in place at conservancy and park level. Mudumu Landscape (excluding Mamili): Buffalo 1 214; Giraffe - 205; Impala 6 795; Wildebeest 2 305 (Source September 2011 Dry Season Count, MET, NACSO); Greater Sossusvlei Landscape: Naukluft Mountains part of the Namib Naukluft Park: Mountain Zebras 2 600 (Source June 2013 Aerial Survey, MET); Greater Waterberg Landscape: Waterberg Plateau Park: Buffalo 550; Roan Antelope 180; Sable Antelope 100 (Source September 2012 helicopter survey, MET); Windhoek Green Belt Landscape: Daan Viljoen Game Park: Oryx 150; Zebras 180 (Source MET estimates only)â€?to â€œKey species collared to monitor wildlife movement in Mudumu and Greater Sossusvlei-Namib Landscapesâ€?) PSC - The change was endorsed. However, the Committee felt that due to the high costs associated with wildlife movement research using collars, the project is to use existing data.
Changes in the movement patterns of animals in relation to corridors created

Partially achieved: There is strong evidence that wild animals are inreasingly using corridors created within Landscapes Conservation Areas. Various Landscape Conservation Areas have shown varrying degrees on corridor usage. Research on wildlife movement using sattelite collars on key species in Mudumu Landscape have shown the usage of corridors with the landscape and wildlife dispersal between Botswana, Namibia, Angola and Zambia. Similar trend has energed in the Greater Sossusvlei-Namib Landscape Conservation Area where preliminary results from the research on wildlife movement have shown fences obstructing wildlife movement and unobstructed movement where fences have been removed or are poorly maintained. In Greater Fish River Canyon Landscape Conservation Area, the annual game census carried out on the Gondwana Private Nature Reserve within the landscape has shown fluctuating population numbers of Mountain Zebra compared to previous annual censuses suggesting that they are moving within the /Ai-/Ais Hot Springs Game Park and adjacent land particularly where fences were removed or poorly maintained due to the rugged terrain.

description.narrative: 5 landscapes are established to improve biodiversity conservation at landscape level; an additional 15,550 km2 brought under collaborative management with protected areas

comment.narrative: 4 existing landscape conservation partnerships in place
5 landscapes established by year 5 with at least 15,550 km2 additional land under collaborative management with protected areas, being ML (1,469), GWL (7,500), GSNL (173), GFRCL (5,750), WGB (658)
Achieved during the reporting period of 2012. The area protected by the established LCAs of 35,049km² significantly exceeds the targeted 15,550km²

description.narrative:
METT scores are improved in protected areas and at landscape level
(The indicator and target on â€œImproved systems level operations capacity has ensured a reduced level of threats to habitats and species composition; Landscapes maintain global biodiversity values; METT scores are improved in protected areas within landscapesâ€? was changed to â€œMETT scores are improved in protected areas and at landscape level\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\") MTR Recommendation - We propose that this indicator is reduced to one that focuses exclusively on the METT scores both at the landscape level (i.e., for each LCA) but also within each of the state-managed protected areas (i.e., there should be a METT score for each LCA and for the state-managed PA in each area).
The aspects of species diversity should be removed it has not been monitored to date, there is no baseline and anyway the project is unlikely to influence species diversity over its lifetime (except, perhaps, an agreement to remove all exotic species from the LCAs).

comment.narrative: Landscape management remains uncoordinated and biodiversity is lost over time. Current METT scores as follows: ML (71) GWL (69), GSNL (37), GFRCL (46), WGB (30): average: 51
METT scores are improved in protected areas and at landscape level
The METT assessment is planned for second half of 2015. The METT assessment carried out in 2013 for the MTR showed an increase by 12 in the average score across the five landscapes.

description.narrative: Framework in place for collaborative management among stakeholders within landscapes.

comment.narrative: Draft MET Protected Area management planning policy guideline in place
Framework for collaborative management among stakeholders within landscapes/ targeted 5 landscapes in place by year 5.

Partially achieved: The National Policy on Protected Areas’ Neighbours and Resident Communities was approved by Cabinet and officially launched. It became the legislation in Namibia that recognizes landscapes Conservation Areas. Further to the policy, The MET with project support developed Implementation Guidelines for the effective implementation of the policy. The policy will pave way for inclusion of landscape conservation into the Protected Areas and Wildlife Management Bill being developed with support from the project.

description.narrative: Key short, medium and long-term development issues identified and disseminated; StrategicManagement plans, based on the key issues for each area, in place for 5 landscapes defining management objectives, standards, rules and procedures for landscape functions.

comment.narrative: Management and development plans for parks (AHGP, NNNP, BMM and Waterberg?) - Draft parks and Wildlife Management Bill (PWMB) and Regulations - Draft PA Management planning policy guideline in place - Environmental Management Act, Draft Regulations and guidelines in place to guide development planning - National CBNRM Framework in place - parks and Neighbours and Concessions policies in place - Draft Protected Area Association of Namibia (PAN) constitution in place (with agreed affiliation by GRFCC , GSNC1 and GWC1) - Draft constitutions in place for GFRCC, GSNC, GWC and MNC. Mudumu south conservancies have constitutions.
Strategic Management plans for each landscape in place by December 2015

Partially achieved: Four of the five Landscape Conservation Areas have approved Strategic Management Plans. Only the Greater Waterberg Landscape Conservation Area is yet to have its draft plan approved by the Landscape Management Committee.

description.narrative: Management and development plans in place for interested landscapes partners (e.g. conservancy, private farm, PA). (Revised in 2013 at Project Steering Committee after partners felt that only interested partners should have management plans)

comment.narrative: Management and development plans for parks (AHGP, NNNP, BMM and Waterberg?) - Draft parks and Wildlife Management Bill (PWMB) and Regulations - Draft PA Management planning policy guideline in place - Environmental Management Act, Draft Regulations and guidelines in place to guide development planning - National CBNRM Framework in place - parks and Neighbours and Concessions policies in place - Draft Protected Area Association of Namibia (PAN) constitution in place (with agreed affiliation by GRFCC , GSNC1 and GWC1) - Draft constitutions in place for GFRCC, GSNC, GWC and MNC. Mudumu south conservancies have constitutions.
Management and development plans are in place for interested landscapes partners by year 5.

Partially achieved: All protected areas within the five landscapes have approved management and tourism development plans. Although all parks have plans, Naute Recreation Resort, Daan Viljoen Game Park and Waterberg Plateau Park are yet to be approved by the Minister.

description.narrative:
Landscape management and development plans in place for all 5 landscapes. This Indicator was incorporated into the Strategic Management Plan Indicator MTR recommendation - The amended version of this indicator (â€œstrategic management plansâ€?) is suitable; no suggested changes.
The Strategic Management Plans are complete for GFRCL, GSNL and Mudumu (notably the three areas with greatest capacity). The Strategic Management Plans for the GWL and WGBL should be completed by Dec 2015 at the latest.

comment.narrative: Management and development plans for parks (AHGP, NNNP, BMM and Waterberg?) - Draft parks and Wildlife Management Bill (PWMB) and Regulations - Draft PA Management planning policy guideline in place - Environmental Management Act, Draft Regulations and guidelines in place to guide development planning - National CBNRM Framework in place - parks and Neighbours and Concessions policies in place - Draft Protected Area Association of Namibia (PAN) constitution in place (with agreed affiliation by GRFCC , GSNC1 and GWC1) - Draft constitutions in place for GFRCC, GSNC, GWC and MNC. Mudumu south conservancies have constitutions.
Management and development plans are in place for each Landscape by year 5.

: Partially achieved: Four of the five Landscape Conservation Areas have approved Strategic Management Plans. Only the Greater Waterberg Landscape Conservation Area is yet to have its draft plan approved by the Landscape Management Committee.

description.narrative: Partnership roles and responsibilities defined and agreed and Partnership Committees in place for each landscape.

comment.narrative: Management committees in place at conservancy and complex level and Park Wardens appointed by MET - Roles and responsibilities of Management committees defined in Management and development plans and in the job descriptions of Park Wardens
Partnership Committee for each landscape in place by year 5.
Achieved. All Landscape Management Committees established in 2012 are still operational.

description.narrative: Incentives and market transformation
Key development issues defined for the SEA (drawing earlier consultation work); SEA in place with recommendations for tourism development in each landscape.

comment.narrative: SEA of the tourism sector completed for the 5 landscapes.

Achieved: All five Landscape Conservation Areas’ Strategic Environmental Assessments of the Tourism Sector for all five Landscape Conservation Areas were developed and adopted by respective landscapes.

description.narrative: Business plans in place for major initiatives supported in landscapes based on SEA recommendations and drawing other existing work. (Revised in 2013 at Project Steering Committee as Business plans at landscapes level was seen as not practical as protected areas are not managed on business principles. Furthermore, private sector partners felt that sharing business plans would compromise individual businesses due to rife competition in the sector)

comment.narrative: Business plans in place for Ai-Ais Hot Springs Game Park and Bwabwata-Mamili-Mudumu (BMM) National Parks; Business and sustainbility plans in place for conservancies in Mudumu North Complex (MNC).
Business plans for major initiatives in 5 landscapes in place by year 5

On-going. The Greater Waterberg Landscape Conservation Area with support from the project is developing Income Generating Options for landscape as a mean to sustain its activities due to limited revenue generation opportunities.

description.narrative: Biodiversity monitoring and assessment system developed for each landscape and recommended at national level for integration into a national tourism venture certification system

comment.narrative: SPAN Biodiversity indicators (being developed at present) - National CBNRM Programme biodiversity indicators published in the State of Conservancy Report (SoCR) - ICEMA biodiversity indicators that would be adopted by MET (for long-term M&E) - NBSAP in place with biodiversity management objectives national level - Local level monitoring (LLM) systems in place at conservancy level; incident (monitoring) books in place for parks. - CPP integrated sustainable land management indicators and Land Degradation Monitoring System (LDMS) with biodiversity indicators.
Biodiversity monitoring indicators in place by year 5 for each landscape and across landscapes.

Partially Achieved: Different landscapes are at different stages of developing monitoring systems. Mudumu Landscape has a well-developed integrated system within protected areas and conservancies that uses the Incident and Event Book Monitoring systems. The Greater Sossusvlei-Namib Namib has developed a Game Count Data Management System for an Integrated Monitoring System for the stakeholders. The first Integrated Landscape Game Count was undertaken across all properties on 20 June 2015. Similarly, the Greater Fish River Canyon Landscape is mirroring efforts from the Greater Sossusvlei-Namib Landscape.

description.narrative: Supply chains developed based on current and potential markets for the diversification of current goods and services and/ or the development of new ones; Supply chains identified for certification; Markets established and mobilised for certified supply chains.

comment.narrative: Cheetah-friendly beef initiative that could be used for lessons learnt and best practices - Current biodiversity-friendly off-take/ harvesting practices by private tourism operators/ game farmers (potentially not documented); Research by ICEMA on indigenous natural products.
Supply chains defined and markets explored/ established for new/ diversified goods and services.

On-going. The project has supported the diversification of current goods and services within landscapes. These include: a) Enhancing the Klein Karas Community resilience to effects of climate change through a community Garden; b) Production of tourist products by Women Sewing Project of Klein Karas Community in Greater Fish River Canyon Landscape; and c) Diversifying livelihood among stakeholders in Windhoek Green Belt Landscape through development of Khomas Hochland Hiking Trail; and d) Development of new tourism route in Mudumu Landscape Conservation Area.

description.narrative: Key operational aspects defined for each landscape; Agreement in place for cost and benefit sharing for each landscape. Indicator was removed MTR Recommendation - This indicator should be nested within the â€œstrategic management plansâ€? that are being produced for each LCA (see Output 2.1 above). Indicator should be removed. PSC - Indicator to be removed as it is nested within the â€œstrategic management plansâ€? that are produced for each LCA

comment.narrative: Current cost sharing arrangement in place at NamibRand Nature Reserve (NRNR); Cost sharing modalities in place in Mudumu between government, private sector and communities.
Cost sharing agreements for each landscape in place by year 5.

title.narrative: Namibia's Third National Communication to the UNFCCC

description.narrative: Namibia’s Self-assessment and Implementation for the preparation of the Third National Communication to the UNFCCC. Expedited Financing of Namibia’s Third National Communications to the UNFCCC.
Namibia’s Self-assessment and Implementation for the preparation of the Third National Communication(NC3) to the UNFCCC
independent political entity

The overall goal of this programme is to foster democracy and strengthen governing institutions through a multi-sectoral approach encompassing support to parliament, judiciary, local government and civil society.

The overall goal of this programme is to foster democracy and strengthen governing institutions through a multi-sectoral approach encompassing support to parliament, judiciary, local government and civil society.
independent political entity
Anti corruption

title.narrative: Improving Policy&Practice Civil Society Capacity Build

description.narrative: Project Title: Improving policy and practice interaction through civil society capacity building through Capacity for knowledge based advocacy increased amongst CSO Groups and Community Voices Heard in the International Arena

title.narrative: Improving policy and practice interaction through civil society capacity building

description.narrative: Improving Policy and practice interaction through civil society capacity building (IPP CSO)
independent political entity
Energy - policy, planning and administration
To empower local grassroots organizations in SSA to participate in and influence the implementation of UNCCD, TerrAfrica and other SLM processes, programs and policies

Number of SLM friendly policies influenced
at local, national or regional levels as a result of CSO and community advocacy

comment.narrative: Civil society in some countries are engaged in advocacy but there is no baseline of policy change due to this advocacy due to lack of monitoring processes

At least 4 countries modifying policies on land as it relates to resource governance and long-term leasing as a result of CSO contribution through advocacy ; At least 4 countries engage in open, widely consultative national debate on impacts of land grabs and biofuels on national heritage and food security as a result of CSO contribution in advocacy.

Africa conference on land grabs was held on 28th and 29th October, 2014 Midrand, South Africa. Result-Continental working group on land grabs constituting members from South Africa, Senegal, Zimbabwe, Kenya and Tanzania was established

description.narrative: Number of communities (or members) adopting best practices learnt from the SLM innovation competitions and documentation

comment.narrative: The Equator initiative is facilitating competitions for innovative initiatives and disseminating lessons learnt, but these do not focus on SLM/LD specifically. There is therefore limited information on a baseline of adoption influenced by the outcomes of such competitions.

This indicator is shared between the CSO and other SIP host projects. At least 10 land managers and/or farmers from the winning initiatives replicate it following publication of the prizes and lessons

Following the successful Equator Prize for SLM held in Kenya, 4 awardees of the prize have held in country celebrations. The celebrations have been supported by UNDP country offices and have been platforms for exchange of ideas and urging other community members to adopt the best practices. The policy makers invited to the in country functions have also been able to see what works and this is one of the initial steps in influencing policy on sustainable land management. Cases in point are Burkina Faso, Benin, Swaziland and Ghana where these in country celebrations took place.

description.narrative: Increased capacity of the CSO community in SSA to advocate emerging SLM issues to regional, national, and sub-national institutions

comment.narrative: There is no documented Baseline on the capacity of CSOs to advocate on emerging SLM issues

By project closure, an advocacy strategy on imparting change to regional, national, and sub-national policies on natural resource governance is prepared and agreed upon by the PSC and the board of the CSO coordination mechanism.
By project closure, a memorandum of understanding is agreed upon with TerrAfrica for recognizing the planned CSO coordination mechanism as their CSO representative partner.

A draft advocacy strategy on imparting change to regional, national and sub national policies on natural resources governance has been prepared but yet to be ratified by the PSC and the board of the coordination mechanism. The draft is attached for review as the process for finalization is on-going.
Secondly, with regard to agreement on memorandum of understanding between the project board and the TerrAfrica on the recognition of the planned CSO mechanism as CSO representative in TerrAfrica, communication is on between the project management unit, PSC members and TerrAfrica and the memorandum will be signed in October during TerrAfrica Board meeting in Ankara, Turkey at the COP12.

description.narrative: Increased resources flowing to SLM from diverse sources

comment.narrative: At the design of the project, there had been an earlier attempt by RIOD as an organization that was working on dryland issues in Sub Saharan Africa. RIOD was evaluated to be a weak institution that had no program of work and the resources to drive the agenda of the institution forward.

By project closure, a strategy is formulated that outlines a sustainable program for recognizing innovation in community-level SLM in SSA; including roles and responsibilities, an operating budget, financing sources, and an outline of managing the process on the website of the CSO coordination mechanism.

The establishment of the coordination mechanism is on course. The mechanism for the CSOs has already been registered in Senegal as Africa Coalition for Sustainable Land Management and draft programme of work developed. A critical stakeholder consultation was held by the end of March 2015 which brainstormed on the strategic objectives and pertinent activities for the institution. The consultations took place during the PSC meeting and the coordination mechanism workshop.

description.narrative: Coordination of African CSOs improved to enhance partnerships for effective coordination and knowledge transfer:
Change in the number of SSA CSO attending UNCCD COPs and CRICs

comment.narrative:
Very few SSA members of the CSO attend the UNCCD events and pre-event preparation is haphazard and non-effective. At COP10 held in the Republic of Korea,
From the UNCCD website, I found that the following 5 CSO’s from SSA participated in the COP 10, the following CSOs from Sub Saharan Africa attended:
1. ENDA Tiers Monde, Senegal; 2. ICLEI, Local Governments for Sustainability, South Africa; 3. Friends of the Earth, Ghana; 4. Association Prudence au Saher, Burkina Faso; 5. Association for Combating Desertification, Ethiopia

At least 35% increase in numbers attending and improvement in pre-event preparations
By project closure, the CSO coordination mechanism develops and agrees to a strategy on facilitating rotational opportunities for CSO’s in each of the three regions to participate in international and regional SLM events.

Even though there was marked improvement (over 100%) increase in the attendance of CSOs at the last COP11 in Namibia, there is a challenge in sustaining the momentum of the number of people attending continuously. For instance, COP12 which is to be held in Ankara, Turkey, the project is targeting and preparing to take at least 12 members of different communities that won the Equator Prize for SLM. Funding for the participation of prospective CSOs members is being mobilized. It worth noting that the target of 12 well over the 35% target given at the design of the project but the overall challenge for the project is for the coordination mechanism to take the facilitation of CSOs to attend the subsequent COPs as one of its responsibilities. In regards to developing a strategy on facilitating rotational opportunities for CSO’s in each of the three regions of sub Saharan Africa to participate in international and regional SLM events, this is part of overall Coordination mechanism strategic plan which is currently being developed. The strategy is among other things focusing on sustaining the flagship activities initiated by the project like attending COPs and other international SLM events.

description.narrative: Effectiveness of CSO preparation for and participation in UNCCD COPs and CRICs and other international fora

comment.narrative: With the exception of the Drynet members, SSA CSO body pre-event preparation is chaotic, there is minimal collaboration between CSO groups outside the UNCCD events

At least 50% increase in pre-event preparedness and quality of participation, indicated by number of discussions held on important topical subjects and positions reached and delivered at the UNCCD events

UNCCD Conference of Parties (COP12) is planned to take place in October 2015 in Ankara, Turkey. In order to improve the preparation for attending the COP, ENDA as Africa Regional Representative in the UNCCD CSO Panel and the implementing partner for outcome II of the project was involved is involved in the planning process. Critical milestones achieved in this regard include:
o Consultation of African CSOs for contributions to the CST4 and the CRIC 13 through email exchange
o Information sharing with more than 50 CSOs through the mailing list about international fora (Desertif’Action Forum-Montpellier (France) June 2015; Social Forum, Tunis, March 2015, all these events have been attended by representatives of the CSOs and discussed the upcoming COP12)
o CST4 and CRIC 13 reports and updates shared as part of the build up to participation at the COP12
o A CSO workshop has been planned for September 2015 with one of the Agenda being preparation of the CSOs for the COP

description.narrative: Extent to which the CSO coordination mechanism is functional, has a program of work and resources

comment.narrative: Currently RIOD is not functional; it has no office, no program of work and no funds. Regional network of representatives have no incentives to implement a RIOD program of work and the network exists only in name

A vision for SLM amongst CSO developed; coordination mechanism registered (is a legal entity in a selected country), program of work and funds raised, a constitution agreed and other modes of operations understood, shared and agreed

The progress made since July 2014 towards the establishment of the functional coordination mechanism include: 1. Sub regional thematic leaders appointed in East, West Central and Southern Africa
2. Registration of the coordination mechanism as a legal entity in Senegal
3. Program of work developed for the coordination mechanism following brainstorming and presentations by the respective thematic leaders
4. Fundraising proposal has been drafted and presented for consideration to Human Rights Initiative within the Open Society Foundations.
The outstanding work to be finalized within the remaining time is the formulation of strategic plan including the resource mobilization component for the mechanism.

description.narrative: Community Innovation in SLM recognized, rewarded and upscaled
Number of SLM innovation competitions organized and awards issued

comment.narrative: The equator initiative currently organizes competitions and gives prizes for communities along the equator, based on innovative biodiversity conservation initiatives that contribute to livelihoods and reduce poverty. Although these have often included initiatives that support SLM, they have not been targeted at the implementation of the UNCCD specifically.

At least 30 Community groups (CBO/CSOs/ NGOs, farmers/herders associations etc.) participate in at least 5 international and regional UNCCD, TerrAfrica, CAADP and other conferences and contribute to debate on policy issues (community dialogue spaces); Local leaders from at least 30 CBOs/CSOs/NGOs and other community groups trained to promote advocacy initiatives

Progress made since July 2014 include a number of milestones as indicated below:
o An Equator Prize Ceremony hosted in New York, on 22 September 2014, for the three finalist SLM winners in which three winners of the Equator Prize for SLM participated in the recognition of best practices at the Global event
o The community dialogues were held at UNDP headquarters in New York City prior to (and after) the Equator Prize ceremony, on 18th, 19th, 20th, and 23rd September 2014; these dialogues were attended by the three winners of the Equator Prize for SLM which had been hosted in June 2014, Nairobi. The dialogue sessions included workshops on grant writing, social marketing and elevator speeches as well as other thematic sessions on fellowships.
o The Equator Initiative —represented by the WIN (World Network of Local and Indigenous Land and Sea Managers) participated in the IUCN World Parks Congress 2014 held in Sydney, Australia, from 12 November to 19 November 2014. At least three community group members from the sub Saharan Africa region participated at the event which among other issues discussed the impact of extractive industry on the communities' livelihoods and conservation areas.

description.narrative: Number and quality of award winning case studies published and disseminated

comment.narrative: Several award winning cases published from the Equator initiative and the UNDP organized Farmer Innovation, but none of them have been specifically targeted on LD/SLM issues
At least 5 publications released and disseminated documenting best practices

As at June 2015, an additional publication on the SLM winners 2014 booklet had been done. The booklet gives the profiles of the 12 winners and showcasing the best practices and the contribution that they have made in their communities in the arena of SLM and poverty reduction. A detailed and in depth publication of the same 12 winners is on course and will be finalized in August 2015.

description.narrative: Number and quality of community dialogues held at national level following CSO/community dialogues at the international fora

comment.narrative: Currently local dialogue being organized for the Equator Initiative price winners but this is not targeted at LD/SLM constituencies
At least 15 local level dialogue facilitated by â€œreturningâ€? communities/ CBOs who attend the international dialogue as potential price winners

Four in-country dialogues have been carried out by the returnees. The dialogues have been organized by the winners of the Equator Prize for SLM and have been hosted in collaboration with UNDP country offices. The in country dialogues have also involved the participation of policy makers and other key stakeholders in the project. These dialogues have taken place in Swaziland, Ghana, Burkina Faso and Benin

description.narrative: CSO Technical Capacity in SLM and knowledge based advocacy increased
Number of current and emerging areas in which CSO produce knowledge based recommendations and advocacy material

comment.narrative: Drynet hosts regular side events with at least one policy paper at each UNCCD event. However, Drynet membership is limited, does not comprehensively cover SSA

At least 8 position papers on topical issues published by CBOs/CSOs/NGOs/ community groups and presented in at least 5 side events (in conjunction with outcome 1). Topics will link effects of policies on SLM practice and poverty reduction e.g. trade, land tenure, governance, carbon finance, etc.;

1- Six country reports (Kenya, Uganda and Tanzania in East Africa and Niger, Ghana and Guinea-Conakry in West Africa) on Social and environmental accountability studies on the extractive industry have been completed. Also finalized are two regional policy briefs synthesizing the findings from east and west African studies on social and environmental accountability in the extractive industry.
2. At the Eastern and Southern Africa CSO, Coordination workshop, 8th -10th October- Dar es salaam, the CSOs took position on GMOs, Natural resource management, mainstreaming of gender in SLM and effective information sharing. 3. In August 2013, the project through ENDA hosted a regional CSOs meeting that took position with regard to the impact of desertification and land degradation leading to food insecurity and loss of income resulting in conflicts. The declaration called for mitigation of land degradation and coordination of CSOs efforts. 4. In June 2014, Equator Prize winners for SLM made a declaration on their commitment to sustainable development, restoring graded lands, conserving their ecosystems for present and future generations and calling on African governments to enhance protection of natural resources.

description.narrative: Number of CSO receiving training in relevant SLM, CC and NRM subjects

comment.narrative: Currently there are many organizations offering training on topical SLM/LD, CC and NRM subjects, but the training is often expensive and not specifically focused on SSA level issues. Many CSO groups are resource poor and cannot afford to self-sponsor for training

At least 4 training courses developed on topical subjects and at least 4 training workshops organized that reach at least 100 CSO groups (with interest). The training made available on line and in hard copies; partnership with an LD/SLM institution facilitated to sustain training
By project closure, a training delivery and development strategy is developed and agreed by the PSC and board of the CSO coordination mechanism.
A draft training delivery and development strategy has been formulated and is to be presented to PSC members for further review before final presentation to the Coordination Mechanism Board.

description.narrative: Number of functional partnerships formed with research institutions

comment.narrative: TBD
At least five partnerships formed with the project

The focus of developing partnership has changed over the last 3 months. This has been re-oriented towards science and technology institutions for the purpose of helping in the building of capacities of CSOs and enhancing the sustainability of the work under outcome 1 for increasing CSO technical capacity for SLM facilitation and knowledge based policy based advocacy. Through secondary literature review and consultation with various development partners, seven science, technology and research institutions have identified and initial consultations have been initiated. These institutions include:
a) African Centre for Technology Studies based in Nairobi Kenya
b) Alliance for a Green Revolution in Africa (AGRA) based in Nairobi Kenya
c) Forum for Agricultural Research in Africa (FARA) based in Accra, Ghana
d) Regional Universities Forum for Capacity Building in Agriculture (RUFORUM) based in Kampala, Uganda
e) African Network for Agriculture, Agroforestry and Natural Resources Education based in Nairobi, Kenya
f) UNDP Dryland Development Centre based UNEP Campus, Nairobi Kenya
g) Technical Centre for Agricultural Rural Cooperation (CTA) based at Wageningen University of Agriculture in the Netherlands
It is estimated that by October, partnerships with at least half of them will have been formalized through signing of MOUs between the Coordination Mechanism Board and the respective institutions.

title.narrative: Concentrating Solar Power Technology Transfer for Electr

description.narrative: Concentrating Solar Power Technology Transfer for Electricity Generation in Namibia (CSP TT) NAM.

title.narrative: Project Dcoument Signature Page Concentrating Solar Power Technology Transfer for Electricity Generation in Namibia (CSP TT) NAM

description.narrative: Concentrating Solar Power Technology Transfer for Electricity Generation in Namibia (CSP TT) NAM.
independent political entity
Energy - power generation

To increase the share of renewable energies in the Namibian energy mix by developing the necessary technological framework and conditions for the successful transfer and deployment of CSP technology for on-grid power generation
Cumulative direct post-project CO2 emission reduction resulting from the investment in CSP by end-of-project (EoP), Mtonnes CO2. % share of CSP in the power generation mix of Namibia by EoP

Cumulative direct post-project CO2 emission reduction resulting from the investment in CSP by end-of-project (EoP), Mtonnes CO2. % share of CSP in the power generation mix of Namibia by EoP NB: Revision of Indicator targets - As per the findings of the Mid-Term Review, these indicators were over-ambitious and cannot be achieved during the project timeframe. Indeed, it is logically impossible to expect a project to achieve post-project emission reductions by the end of the project. The indicators were not sufficiently amended to reflect the project redesign requested by GEFSec during the protracted project preparation phase. Specifically, the indicators do not accurately reflect the revised goal of the project, which is to have the feasibility study for a CSP plant in place by the end of the project, not to construct the plant itself.
Local entrepreneurs are engaged in the manufacturing, supply and installation of CSP systems

Number of government-endorsed CSP partnerships established by Year 3 Number of local CSP engineering design firms with CSP design experience established and operational by Year 3 Number of local CSP-related manufacturing, supply and installation companies by Year 3
Increased investments in CSP technology applications in Namibia

Number of sites where investment-grade solar resource data is available by Year 2 No. of CSP investments facilitated by the CSP development guidelines by Year 3 that are streamlined with REPM outcomes Number of planned and approved CSP technology application projects that are funded by local financing institutions by EoP and in line with REPM outcomes
Increased installed capacity of CSP plants in Namibia

Number of planned, approved and financed CSP projects that replicate the first CSP investment by EOP Cumulative installed power generation capacity from CSP plants by EOP, MW Set of specific regulations promoting the development and operation of CSP plants that are in turn mainstreamed into the NERL and REPM guidelines

NB: Revision of Indicator targets - As per the findings of the Mid-Term Review, these indicators were over-ambitious and cannot be achieved during the project timeframe. The indicators were not sufficiently amended to reflect the project redesign requested by GEFSec during the protracted project preparation phase. Specifically, the indicators do not accurately reflect the revised goal of the project, which is to have the feasibility study for a CSP plant in place by the end of the project, not to construct the plant itself.

description.narrative: Implementation of the Integrated Fire Management Strategy
8. Number of hectares under improved integrated fire management

comment.narrative: SOPs are currently not in place
100% of Namibia’s PAs (135,906 ha)

National Fire Management Strategy developed and approved.
ToR for development of SOP for each PA finalized.
Improved Fire Management practices, Namely: (a) Introduction of Early Burning to minimize biomas / fire load as a strategy to counter adverse fire impacts during the fire season, (b) maintenance of fire-breaks and (c) creation of new fire breaks - where necessary, to contain, limit and confine fire outbreaks to smaller areas / burned patches at a time. For the reporting period, these activities were predominantly implemented in Etosha (2,227,000 ha), Khaudum (384,000 ha) and Bwabwata (610,000 ha) = (3,221,000 ha in total.

title.narrative: Namibia’s Second Biennial Update Report (BUR 2 NAM) to t

description.narrative: Namibia’s Second Biennial Update Report (BUR 2 NAM) to t

Project involves the preparation of BUR 2 for submission to the Conference of Parties (COP) of the UNFCCC, at its 22nd session in 2016, in accordance with its commitment as a party to the Convention as per Decision 2/CP.17 taken at COP 17.
The project will support government efforts to develop and implement policies aimed at eradicating poverty in Namibia

title.narrative: Project Proposal TRAC Namibia El Nino

description.narrative: Support the Government of Namibia in its war against poverty
Support to El Nino Drought Emergency Response
This Programme Support project has been developed to provide technical backstopping to UNDP Implementing partners for UNDP funded projects.
The Programme Support Project developed through direct project costing provisions will ensure capacity transfer for effective project management for all UNDP funded projects
